quoteLast: , and stood looking from her window at the green park, with its great bare spreading trees below her. Only a quarter to nine! What should she do with herself till breakfast time? At this hour at home, breakfast would be a thing of the past, and father and Hugh have gone off to the hospital. And mother would have done a hundred and one things before settling down to teaching the girls; and the boys would have been off—the younger ones to school, and Hal to King’s College.
title: Sydney Lisle, the Heiress of St. Quentin
author: Moore, Dorothea, 1880-1933; Paget, Walter, 1863-1935 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: We found the trenches much improved as regards water, but still in need of most urgent attention to prevent a complete collapse of all breastworks. Except for one or two angry bursts on Tissage Dump, the enemy was exceedingly quiet; and at
quoteLast: on February 14th, the first anniversary of our departure for France, we handed over to the 13th Welch and said good-bye to Houplines. Of the many men who served with the battalion, few, if any, will look back on Houplines without some feeling akin to affection.
title: The History of the 2/6th (Rifle) Battalion, "the King's" (Liverpool Regiment) 1914-1919
author: Wurtzburg, C. E. (Charles Edward), 1891-1952

quoteLast: --Remounted. Continued Seljaland valley; ponds on both sides with and without drains. View of Snæfellsjökull. On left porcupine-shaped Helgafell.
title: Ultima Thule; or, A Summer in Iceland. vol. 2/2
author: Burton, Richard Francis, Sir, 1821-1890

quoteFirst: The grandfather's clock is ticking audibly. It is
quoteLast: The gas over desk is lighted_.
title: Three Plays: The Fiddler's House, The Land, Thomas Muskerry
author: Colum, Padraic, 1881-1972

quoteFirst: After breakfast we muster again and a gentleman talks to us in a voice that would lead you to believe that he thought we were all in hiding somewhere in New Rochelle. Then there are any number of things to do to divert our minds--scrub hammocks, pick up cigarettes, drill, hike and attend lectures. As a rule we do all of these things. From 5 p.m. until
quoteLast: if we are unfortunate enough not to have a lecture party we are free to give ourselves over to the riotous joy of the moment, which consists of listening to a phonograph swear bitterly at a piano long past its prime. The final act of the drama of the day is performed on the hammock--an animated little sketch of arms and legs conducted along the lines of Houdini getting into a strait-jacket, or does he get out of them? I don't know, perhaps both.
title: Biltmore Oswald
author: Smith, Thorne, 1892-1934; Dorgan, Dick, 1892-1953 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: He used to go to people and say, 'I'm having a little trouble reading this,' and then he'd hold his wrist up." Richard raised his arm proudly out in front of him. "And he'd squint, as if he had eye trouble. 'Oh, it's a
quoteLast: ,' they'd say." Richard threw back his head and laughed. "My dad was a great guy--could barely read, always singing. He worked on the docks.
title: O+F
author: Wetterau, John Moncure

quoteFirst: The orderly, with an obese bundle of washing on his back, plods from the ward to the Dirty Linen Store at
quoteLast: every morning. I say he "plods" because the bundle is generally too heavy for transportation at a rapid pace. Twenty sheets are usually but a part of the bundle; and twenty sheets are alone no light burden.
title:
Observations of an Orderly
Some Glimpses of Life and Work in an English War Hospital

quoteFirst: A rare figure of an athlete he was, and a rare athlete's day his was in that retreat. For hours before he called and turned out the morning guard he had been up busy gardening, or reading, or writing. At a
quoteLast: he breakfasted. Very shortly after breakfast an ex-champion sculler the admirable Bill East, would arrive from Richmond, and he and Sir Charles would row in a racing skiff a measured mile or more of the river.
title: The Life of the Rt. Hon. Sir Charles W. Dilke, Volume 2

quoteFirst: Dinner gets pushed back later and later; we really must reform. Last night we did not sit down till
quoteLast: . The nights are divinely cool; we go to the terrace from the dinner-table, and sit there till bedtime under the friendly stars.

quoteFirst: Rivers had everything “fixed” by that hour, including herself presumably, for she had put on a gray dress which she usually wore when shopping in the county town, adding a prim collar and cuffs. A pearl-encircled brooch, the wedding gift of Seth, and a solitaire ring next to her wedding ring, with a locket containing her children's hair, accented her position as a proper wife and mother. At a
quoteLast: she had finished tidying the parlor, opening the harmonium so that the light might play upon its polished keyboard, and bringing from the forgotten seclusion of her closet two beautifully bound volumes of Tupper's “Poems” and Pollok's “Course of Time,” to impart a literary grace to the centre table.
title: Trent's Trust, and Other Stories
author: Harte, Bret, 1836-1902

quoteFirst: 55, “five minutes with the daily news;” 9 a.m., class work begins; 12, class work closes; 12.15 p.m., dinner; 1 p.m., work bell; 1.30 p.m., class work begins; 3.30 p.m., class work ends; 5.30 p.m., bell to “knock off” work; 6 p.m., supper; 7.10 p.m., evening prayers; 7.30 p.m., evening study hours;
quoteLast: , evening study hour closes; 9.20 p.m., warning retiring bell; 9.30 p.m., retiring bell.
title: Up from Slavery: An Autobiography
author: Washington, Booker T., 1856-1915

quoteFirst: Here the _Spey_ is crossed at its junction with the _Truim_, and then the road ascends for ten miles more to _Dalwhinnie_. It became cold and windy with occasional rain. At length, and not till a
quoteLast: , we reached the inn of _Dalwhinnie_,--29 miles from where we had left our ponies,--which stands by itself, away from any village. Here, again, there were a few people assembled, and I thought they knew us; but it seems they did not, and it was only when we arrived that one of the maids recognized me. She had seen me at _Aberdeen_ and _Edinburgh_.
title: Leaves From the Journal of Our Life in the Highlands, From 1848 to 1861
author: Victoria, Queen of Great Britain, 1819-1901; Helps, Arthur, Sir, 1813-1875 [Editor]
